   return true;
   }
else

}

       if (helpWin) helpWin.focus()
   }
}

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=12821">First Year Writing Tutorial - 12821 - ACEN 100 - 1</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Develop essential writing knowledge and skills including planning, writing thesis statements, researching, citing, revising, and editing. Gain confidence through practicing writing in-class and workshopping writing from other classes. This course is appropriate for students with first year status at Earlham.

<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Appropriate for first-year
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />

       1.000 Credits

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=12818">Advance Writing Tutorial - 12818 - ACEN 300 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course will help students navigate the difficulties of extended writing, explore career-based writing, and discuss genres of writing essential for graduate school and job applications. This course is suitable for students with junior or senior status who are looking toward future writing situations and long-term writing projects.
<br />

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13524">Advanced Arabic: Listening - 13524 - ARBC 303 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This is an advanced Arabic course focusing specifically on listening comprehension.
We will make use of listening materials in both colloquial Levantine Arabic and Modern
Standard. Materials will range widely in content and topic in order to give students the
most exposure possible to different levels of language.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13578">3D Modeling & Creating Art - 13578 - ART 240 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course will serve as an introduction to the use of 3D modeling for artistic production through the program Rhinoceros, as well as fabrication techniques using 3D Printing and Laser Cutting. In this course you will acquire a technical proficiency of 3D modeling in order to create successful 3D computer-generated models or renderings that are applicable to your creative area. Course topics will not only include instruction on the operation of these tools, but on the creative process and the creation of art in general. Course Fee: $150
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13549">Modern Art & the Environment - 13549 - ART 282 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course explores how self-consciously modern artists have engaged with ecological thought and responded to environmental change. Through the close reading of objects, primary sources, and recent ecocritical scholarship, students will investigate how the environment has shaped the production of art and the production of art history alike.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016

<br />

<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13028">The Arts of the Midwest - 13028 - ART 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This seminar will nurture innovative research projects on the arts of the Midwest. Independent research will be complemented by object-based case studies on the visual cultures of the region. Taking students from Cahokia to the contemporary, these collaborative investigations will help students orient their own work within the existing field.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Arts -Theoretical & Historical, Prerequisite Required, Research Intensive, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=10039">Gym Climbing - 10039 - AWPE 201 - 1</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
An introduction to the sport of climbing.  This course takes place in the first 7 weeks of the semester.  This class will involve 5 introductory classes and an additional 10 documented hours of open climbing throughout the semester.  Fee: $95.00 (includes semester climbing pass).  IMPORTANT: First class meeting: Monday, August 29 at 7 pm at the Wellness Center.  Only students registered on Self-Service AND present at the first class will be enrolled.  Due to limited enrollment, there will be no refunds after the first class.  Over-enrolled courses are registered by lottery.

</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Fee: $95.00 - Increase climbing strength, enhance technique and delve deeper into the complex world of climbing. This course takes place in the first seven weeks of the semester. This class will involve five classes and an additional 10 hours of climbing outside of class throughout the semester. Course fee includes semester climbing pass. Pre-requisite: Indoor Gym Climbing or permission of instructor(s). IMPORTANT: First class meeting: Thursday, September 1 at 7pm at Wellness Center. Only students registered on Self-Service AND present at the first class will be enrolled. Due to limited enrollment, there will be no refunds after the first class. </tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Fee: $200 - Experience the beauty and excitement of outdoor climbing over Early Semester Break (Oct 5-9)! This trip is open to beginners and will involve a pre-trip meeting and a 4-day climbing trip. Previous destinations include Devils Lake State Park (Wisconsin). IMPORTANT: The mandatory pre-trip meeting will be at the Outdoor Education Center on Monday, September 5, at 12 P.M. Only students registered on Self-Service AND present at the first class will be enrolled. Due to limited enrollment, there will be no refunds after the add/drop period. <tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=12153">Backpacking - 12153 - AWPE 207 - 1</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Fee: $150 - Backpacking is an introductory course open to students who want to enjoy the simple pleasures of hiking and cooking outside. Course instructors are fellow Earlham students who have a passion for backpacking and additional training through other courses including Outdoor Trip Leadership and Wilderness First Responder. The trip corresponds with the College's Early Semester Break (Oct 5-9) and equates to about 4 nights on trail. Destinations for previous trips have included trails within Hoosier National Forest and Dolly Sods Wilderness (West Virginia). Backpacking is .5 credits and counts towards the Wellness requirements in General Education. IMPORTANT: The mandatory pre-trip meeting will be at the Outdoor Education Center on Thursday, September 8 at 12 P.M. Only students registered on Self-Service AND present at the first class will be enrolled. Due to limited enrollment, there will be no refunds after the add/drop period. Over-enrolled courses are registered by lottery.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13415">Canoe Instructor - 13415 - AWPE 300 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Fee: $150 - This course will travel to a nearby location to practice American Canoe Association Level 1 canoeing skills and group management. Students will have the opportunity to complete an ACA L1 assessment at the end of the course. This trip will involve a pre-trip meeting and a weekend paddling trip to a river or lake in Indiana. Trip Dates: Sept 9-11. IMPORTANT: The mandatory pre-trip meeting will be at the Outdoor Education Center on Thursday, September 1 at 12 P.M. Only students registered on Self-Service AND present at the first class will be enrolled. Due to limited enrollment, there will be no refunds after the add/drop period. Over-enrolled courses are registered by lottery.

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=11770">Student Research - 11770 - BIOL 486 - 1</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This research class will be a hands on opportunity where you will join Wendy in the field and learn different field techniques and analyses used to study birds (from mist netting and banding to bird census techniques, and analyzing the data).  You will examine what bird species are using the different habitats present in back campus, how species composition and abundances change over time, and how we can manage EC properties to better support our bird community.  You might also have the opportunity to create interpretative materials to promote natural history walks in back campus. If you are interested contact Wendy ASAP
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Immersion Experience, Instructor Signature Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Research Schedule Type
<br />
       2.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13553">Climate Change Impacts & Adapt - 13553 - ENSC 341 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course investigates the impacts of climate change on ecosystems and the human systems they support, using real-world case studies, and explores the actions communities are taking to adapt to climate change. Readings in systems theory will develop a systems-thinking lens through which to view these problems and consider solutions. Pre-requisites: At least 2 of these classes: BIOL 111, ENST 240, or GEOL 201/211 (or other relevant course, subject to instructor approval).
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Enrollment Limit, Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13550">Environmental Application - 13550 - ENSC 353 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This applied course guides students in developing an interdisciplinary research toolkit with which to approach environmental problem solving. Each week we will learn a method through readings, lectures, and discussion, and then practice using it during in-class activities and homework assignments. As an outcome, students will be familiar with several methods from the natural and social sciences that are commonly used in environmental careers, as well as interdisciplinary techniques such as scenarios planning, integrative assessment, and adaptive management. The course culminates with a student-directed, interdisciplinary project. Pre-requisites: ENST 240 and at least 1 lab course in the natural sciences.



<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Prerequisite Required, Scientific Inquiry, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus

       3.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13548">Modern Art and the Environ - 13548 - ENST 282 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course explores how self-consciously modern artists have engaged with ecological thought and responded to environmental change. Through the close reading of objects, primary sources, and recent ecocritical scholarship, students will investigate how the environment has shaped the production of art and the production of art history alike.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Arts -Theoretical & Historical, Cross Listed Course, Appropriate for first-year

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13547">Eco-Spirituality: Global Traditions - 13547 - ENST 340 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Eco-spirituality encompasses scholarly study with practiced activism at the intersection between world religions on the one hand, and ecology and environmentalism on the other. The term eco-spirituality refers to individual as well as organizational ideas and actions, with a focus on interactions between biotic systems and their environments and to ethical matters of environmental concern. In this course, students engage the complex and diverse spiritualities of human relationship with the natural world. Among the traditions explored are Roman Catholicism, indigenous traditions in the Americas and Africa, Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism. The query of environmentalism as the new spirituality of global awareness and responsibility is investigated. Students formulate their own framework of eco-spirituality.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Appropriate for first-year, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13552">Climate Change Impacts & Adapt - 13552 - ENST 341 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course investigates the impacts of climate change on ecosystems and the human systems they support, using real-world case studies, and explores the actions communities are taking to adapt to climate change. Readings in systems theory will develop a systems-thinking lens through which to view these problems and consider solutions. Pre-requisites: At least 2 of these classes: BIOL 111, ENST 240, or GEOL 201/211 (or other relevant course, subject to instructor approval).
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13551">Environmental Application - 13551 - ENST 353 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This applied course guides students in developing an interdisciplinary research toolkit with which to approach environmental problem solving. Each week we will learn a method through readings, lectures, and discussion, and then practice using it during in-class activities and homework assignments. As an outcome, students will be familiar with several methods from the natural and social sciences that are commonly used in environmental careers, as well as interdisciplinary techniques such as scenarios planning, integrative assessment, and adaptive management. The course culminates with a student-directed, interdisciplinary project. Pre-requisites: ENST 240 and at least 1 lab course in the natural sciences.



<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Prerequisite Required, Scientific Inquiry, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13460">Environmental Racism and Community Health - 13460 - ENST 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course engages students in a sustained consideration of environmental racism -- the correlation between hazardous or degraded environments on the one hand, and communities of color on the other -- in the United States. Students will learn about the extent and nature of effects of industrial operations on communities, and the various systemscultural, institutional, economic, politicalthat serve to maintain these conditions generation after generation. A major focus of the class will be the health problems associated with industrial pollution and disproportionately borne by people of color, as well as strategies utilized to address them.  Course Fee: $50.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Diversity-Domestic, Enrollment Limit, Upper Level Requirement, Wellness
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits
<br />
<a href="/pls/frog/bwckctlg.p_display_courses?term_in=201710&amp;one_subj=ENST&amp;sel_crse_strt=382&amp;sel_crse_end=382&amp;sel_subj=&amp;sel_levl=&amp;sel_schd=&amp;sel_coll=&amp;sel_divs=&amp;sel_dept=&amp;sel_attr=">View Catalog Entry</a>

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13577">History of Modern MENA - 13577 - HIST 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
We will explore the key processes, events, and people that have shaped the Middle East since the mid-19th century. I hope this will help you better contextualize current developments, think about how to be a historian, and especially for studying Middle East history, and gain familiarity with a range of sources, including academic writing, fiction, film, and non-fiction.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Diversity-International, Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13528">Student-Led Course - 13528 - INTD 120 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
The course will encompass the biopsychosocial aspects of the global health phenomenon of HIV/AIDS, focusing primarily on the biology behind HIV and AIDS, and also examining psychological impacts on patients through narratives, and social movements in response to the AIDS epidemic through historical accounts and modern sociological evidence.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
StudentDesigned/Led Course Schedule Type
<br />
       1.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13535">Miller Farm Sustainable Agriculture Practicum - 13535 - INTD 121 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
The main focus of this course is to be a practicum in sustainable agriculture. We will be using a variety of techniques, including observing the land and ecology, using manures and compost, seed planting and saving, participating in various forms of sustainable agriculture, harvesting, and other farm work. We would have Mexican farmers from the Richmond community come to speak to us about their traditional/indigenous agriculture and what sustainable agriculture means to them. The instructor will facilitate students designing and implementing an experimental agricultural project of their choosing while also working on projects already happening on the farm.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       1.000 Credits
<br />

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13582">Leonhard Euler and his Mathematics - 13582 - INTD 122 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
The objective of this course is to inspire students to think about mathematics questions in different aspects rather than rigorously following the mechanics of solving problems. Through reading Eulers works, students explore how a great mathematician think about problems and become capable of solving problems themselves. This course will focus on Eulers contributions on numerous mathematical fields, including number theory, complex numbers, geometry and calculus. Especially designed for freshmen and sophomores who are interested in studying mathematics as their major / minor. We also welcome students who demonstrate strong interest in mathematics.
Pre-requisite: High-school algebra. Calculus exposure is recommended.

<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Appropriate for first-year, Prerequisite Required
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
StudentDesigned/Led Course Schedule Type
<br />
       1.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13576">History of Modern MENA - 13576 - JWST 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
We will explore the key processes, events, and people that have shaped the Middle East since the mid-19th century. I hope this will help you better contextualize current developments, think about how to be a historian, and especially for studying Middle East history, and gain familiarity with a range of sources, including academic writing, fiction, film, and non-fiction.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Diversity-International, Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13544">Networks, Crowds, & Markets - 13544 - MATH 240 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
We live in a highly connected world. Reasoning about these connections is necessary for understanding social, economic, political and other markets to understand applications like : selecting newsfeed stories, networking for a job, picking an Ebay bid, analyzing power dynamics.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>AR - Abstract, Cross Listed Course
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13543">Activism Beyond Ego - 13543 - PAGS 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Transformative activism requires both spiritual and critical foundations. How do we recognize the radical contingency yet decisive power of individual and social identities? How do we negotiate painful differences and conflicts without separating self and other? What is the true nature of freedom and liberation? We will examine spiritual and social theories of identity and agency and concrete global examples of spiritually based transformative activism, with application to political issues on the Earlham campus. Prerequisite: ESEM II or consent of the instructor
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Diversity-International, Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits
<br />
<a href="/pls/frog/bwckctlg.p_display_courses?term_in=201710&amp;one_subj=PAGS&amp;sel_crse_strt=382&amp;sel_crse_end=382&amp;sel_subj=&amp;sel_levl=&amp;sel_schd=&amp;sel_coll=&amp;sel_divs=&amp;sel_dept=&amp;sel_attr=">View Catalog Entry</a>

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13588">Nationalism and Ethnic Conflict - 13588 - POLS 344 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course analyzes the structural, political, economic, social, cultural, and perceptual factors that lead to internal conflicts. It reviews the theories related to the nature and source of ethnic nationalism; investigates the onset , strategies, and termination of ethnic conflict; considers the role of international military intervention; and applies these theories to selected case studies.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Diversity-International, Prerequisite Required, S=Simulation, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13468">History Modern Middle East and North Africa - 13468 - POLS 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
We will explore the key processes, events, and people that have shaped the Middle East since the mid-19th century. I hope this will help you better contextualize current developments, think about what it means to be a historian, and especially of the Middle East and North Africa, and gain familiarity with a range of sources, including academic writing, fiction, film, and non-fiction.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13587">Analytical Issues in Latin American Politics - 13587 - POLS 384 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course provides students with the theoretical and analytical tools to engage in cross-national study and research of political porcesses in Latin America. It explores alternative theorectical approaches as well as substantive topics of central importance for the study of Latin American politics as well as for the sub-field of Comparative Politics.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Diversity-International, Enrollment Limit, Prerequisite Required, R=Research, Upper Level Requirement, Writing Intensive
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13586">Brazilian Politics and Society - 13586 - POLS 389 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course analyzes the main historical phases and appraises alternative interpretations of the political systems as prisms through which to understand a great variety of national and sub-national experiences in Brazeil. It also examines key institutions, processes, and global forces and systems shaping politics, economics, culture, and society in Brazil.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />

<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>A=Argument, Diversity-International, Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13546">Eco-Spirituality: Global Traditions - 13546 - REL 340 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Eco-spirituality encompasses scholarly study with practiced activism at the intersection between world religions on the one hand, and ecology and environmentalism on the other. The term eco-spirituality refers to individual as well as organizational ideas and actions, with a focus on interactions between biotic systems and their environments and to ethical matters of environmental concern. In this course, students engage the complex and diverse spiritualities of human relationship with the natural world. Among the traditions explored are Roman Catholicism, indigenous traditions in the Americas and Africa, Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism. The query of environmentalism as the new spirituality of global awareness and responsibility is investigated. Students formulate their own framework of eco-spirituality.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Appropriate for first-year, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits
<br />
<a href="/pls/frog/bwckctlg.p_display_courses?term_in=201710&amp;one_subj=REL&amp;sel_crse_strt=340&amp;sel_crse_end=340&amp;sel_subj=&amp;sel_levl=&amp;sel_schd=&amp;sel_coll=&amp;sel_divs=&amp;sel_dept=&amp;sel_attr=">View Catalog Entry</a>

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13541">Activism Beyond Ego - 13541 - REL 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Transformative activism requires both spiritual and critical foundations. How do we recognize the radical contingency yet decisive power of individual and social identities? How do we negotiate painful differences and conflicts without separating self and other? What is the true nature of freedom and liberation? We will examine spiritual and social theories of identity and agency and concrete global examples of spiritually based transformative activism, with application to political issues on the Earlham campus. Prerequisite ESEM II or consent of instructor.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Diversity-International, Prerequisite Required, Upper Level Requirement
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits

<tr>
<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13496">Environmental Racism and Community Health - 13496 - SOAN 382 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
This course engages students in a sustained consideration of environmental racism -- the correlation between hazardous or degraded environments on the one hand, and communities of color on the other -- in the United States. Students will learn about the extent and nature of effects of industrial operations on communities, and the various systemscultural, institutional, economic, politicalthat serve to maintain these conditions generation after generation. A major focus of the class will be the health problems associated with industrial pollution and disproportionately borne by people of color, as well as strategies utilized to address them.  Course Fee: $50.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Cross Listed Course, Diversity-Domestic, Enrollment Limit, Upper Level Requirement, Wellness
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Lecture Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits
<br />

<th CLASS="ddtitle" scope="colgroup" ><a href="/pls/frog/bwckschd.p_disp_detail_sched?term_in=201710&amp;crn_in=13545">Cosplay - 13545 - THEA 182 - 0</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<TD CLASS="dddefault">
Learn how to take a drawing of a character and bring them to life. In this course, you will be guided through the process of creating your very own cosplay costume, hair and makeup. With the aid of research, construction and creative problem solving you will experience first-hand what it takes to create a costume, hair and makeup design that embodies your cosplay character.
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Associated Term: </SPAN>EC Fall Semester 2016-17
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Registration Dates: </SPAN>Apr 11, 2016 to Apr 15, 2016
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Levels: </SPAN>Undergraduate
<br />
<SPAN class="fieldlabeltext">Attributes: </SPAN>Art Applied, Enrollment Limit
<br />
<br />
Earlham College Campus
<br />
Applied Schedule Type
<br />
       3.000 Credits
